The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  countries1 strongly  believe  that  adopting  a 
regional approach to energy sector management would promote affordable, sustainable, and 
secure energy supplies. Given each country’s individual energy needs and varying resource 
endowment, the regional approach allows for identification of the most cost-efficient projects 
and  diversification  of  sources  to  enhance  energy  supply  security  within  the  GMS  in  an 
environment-friendly  manner.  The  governments  of  GMS  countries  requested  technical 
assistance (TA)2 from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to promote low carbon technologies 
including renewable energy (such as biomass, solar, wind, and micro and/or mini-hydro); clean 
fuels (such as biofuels and natural gas); and energy efficiency measures. The design and 
monitoring framework for the regional TA is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES  
2.  The  GMS  has  made  significant  progress  in  power  sector  integration  through  the 
Regional Power Trade and Coordination Committee (RPTCC). Similar opportunities exist in the 
areas of renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency that can help secure additional 
sources  of  energy  while  meeting  national  targets  in  greenhouse  gas  (GHG)  reductions. 
Facilitation of investment and transfer of low carbon technologies will be critical in meeting the 
subregion’s development objectives. In the last decade, some of the GMS countries more than 
others have made significant progress in the areas of renewable energy, clean fuels, and 
energy efficiency. Therefore, considerable knowledge and lessons can be shared among the 
countries. Further, given the different stages of economic development of the GMS countries; 
there are significant opportunities for indigenization of the technologies within the countries and 
to lower costs.  
 
3.        Notwithstanding these opportunities, regional cooperation on clean energy has lagged 
behind, owing to the lack of a shared vision on clean energy cooperation, and a regional 
platform that could stimulate enhanced cooperation. To address this shortcoming, the GMS 
Road Map for Expanded Cooperation in the Energy Sector was adopted in June 2009 by the 
15th  GMS  Ministerial  Conference.  According  to  this  road  map,  maintaining  energy  supply 
security,  accessibility,  affordability,  and  environmental  sustainability  are  important  energy 
objectives of the GMS countries, given widespread energy poverty in the subregion. The GMS 
Sustainable Energy Forum (SEF) was identified as the implementing network for facilitating 
improved regional cooperation. The SEF however, is in its infancy, and dedicated support is 
needed for it to evolve into a vibrant GMS-wide platform for sharing knowledge and experience.  
 
4.  The current regional TA supported by ADB is designed to provide direct and key support 
for implementation of the GMS Road Map for Expanded Cooperation in the Energy Sector and 
strongly supports the GMS countries’ climate change mitigation efforts by facilitating investment 
and transfer of more sustainable and environment-friendly energy supply options.  The TA 
supports sustainable economic growth, which is the core strategic area of ADB’s Strategy 
2020.3 The project complements all the Strategy 2020 cross-cutting themes of promoting the 
role of the private sector in development, supporting regional cooperation and integration for 
development, and addressing environmental sustainability. The TA is consistent with the GMS

regional  cooperation  operations  business  plan,  2010–2012.4 The  project  is  expected  to 
contribute to the implementation of GMS regional integration efforts under the new long-term 
GMS Strategic Framework, 2012–2022. The framework for which is being currently developed, , 
taking into account emerging global and regional trends and challenges, will  inform a new 
strategic vision for GMS economic cooperation and provide the necessary goals and action 
plans for the GMS program, 2012–2022. During implementation, the TA will take into account 
the results of a preliminary study assessing the strategies and options on rural renewable 
energy development completed recently by the GMS Working Group on Agriculture, and will 
provide inputs to the various rural and renewable energy development investment projects that 
are being developed by the ADB within GMS countries, and are included in the countries’ 
operations business plan pipelines.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
5.  The impact of the TA will be to enhance the supply of energy in the GMS in a resource-
efficient  and  environment-friendly  manner for economic growth  and poverty  reduction. The 
outcome of the TA will be the effective transfer of low carbon practices and technologies within 
the GMS. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
6.  The TA will be implemented under the auspices of the SEF and will aim to realize the 
objectives of the GMS Road Map for Expanded Cooperation in the Energy Sector. The SEF will 
also be the vehicle for dissemination of knowledge and experiences that are accumulated 
through the activities of the TA. In addition to the periodic meetings of the SEF, the TA will also 
conduct specific training workshops and consultations on selected renewable energy, clean fuel, 
and energy efficiency technologies, practices, and business models.  
 
7.  Specifically, the TA will produce the following outputs: 
 
(i)  the SEF strengthened as the forum for information exchange and knowledge sharing 
on  renewable  energy,  clean  fuels,  and  energy  efficiency;  and  as  the  forum  for 
networking and technical exchanges between planners/policy makers and the private 
sector;  
 
(ii)  a regional database of best practices and technologies on renewable energy, clean 
fuels, and energy efficiency developed, to be linked with existing databases such as 
the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the RPTCC; 
 
(iii)  subregional performance targets developed for use of renewable energy and clean 
fuels, and energy efficiency savings; 
(iv)  renewable energy and clean fuels resources, and energy efficiency potential map 
produced  for  all  GMS  countries,  with  a  technology-  and-cost-based  ranking  of 
various options; and 
(v)  business models identified for deployment of selected energy efficiency, renewable 
energy, and clean fuels technologies based on the local conditions of each GMS

country; and at least five pilot project proposals identified for financing by ADB and 
other financing agencies.   
 
8.  The business models to be developed under the TA will include the following features: 
(i) suitable technology adapted to local conditions; (ii) specific policy package in support of the 
selected  technology;  (iii)  significant  local  content  in  manufacturing  of  the  equipment; 
(iv) definition of the role of public and private investors; and (v) competitive cost (investment, 
operation,  and  maintenance).  Pilot  projects  will  be  designed  using  the  business  models 
developed under the TA. Since GMS countries are in different stages of development, the 
business models will have to be tailored for each GMS country for the selected renewable, 
clean fuel, and energy efficiency technology; and the technology will have to be transferred from 
one GMS country to another with knowledge transfer and capacity development. In this regard, 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Thailand will not be hosting pilot projects, but they 
can provide the knowledge to other GMS countries where the pilot projects will be implemented.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
9.  The total cost of the TA will be $1,000,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund5 (for GMS countries other than the PRC) and $200,000 
will be financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Clean Energy Fund6 (for the PRC), both 
under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility, and administered by ADB. The detailed 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
10.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA  and  will  provide  administration  and 
technical  support  services  through  the  Environmental  Operations  Center  (EOC)7 based  in 
Bangkok, Thailand. Within ADB, the project will be managed by the Southeast Asia Energy and 
Water Division.  
 
The focal points for each participating country will be the ministries or agencies responsible for 
preparation of the power sector development plan. The focal points will be defined by the 
respective countries and individual representatives established prior to commencement of the 
TA. The focal points for the TA will participate in the meetings of the SEF and relevant sessions 
of the RPTCC. 
 
11.  The TA will require the services of a consulting firm for 48 person-months (including 
20 person-months  international  and  28  person-months  national  consultants).  The  terms  of 
reference  for  consultants  are  in  Appendix  3.  ADB  will  select  and  engage  consultants  in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time).

computing hardware and other related expenses. The EOC on its part will provide (out of its own budget) a half-
time TA technical coordinator, based at EOC, which would support the ADB project officer.

4   
The simplified technical proposal procedure will be used for selecting the consulting firm based 
on the quality- and cost-based selection process at a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. Disbursements 
under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will commence in February 2011 and 
be implemented over a period of 24 months. The consultant will prepare inception, interim, draft 
final  and  final  reports.  In  addition,  the  consultant  will  also  develop  technical  reports  and 
assessments as identified in the work plan and conduct training sessions and the annual GMS 
SEF meetings. The EOC will assist in the identification and selection of the national consultants. 
All procurement will be done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The TA outputs will be disseminated by a variety of means, 
including website publication, in-country workshops, electronic reports, and other means to be 
specified in a knowledge dissemination action plan, to be prepared as part of the inception 
report.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
12.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership 
Facility,  and  (ii)  ADB  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$200,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Clean Energy Fund under the 
Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility, both for Promoting Renewable Energy, Clean 
Fuels, and Energy Efficiency in the Greater Mekong Subregion, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

Appendix 3     8  
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A consulting firm will be recruited for a total of 48 person-months, including 20 person-
months of international consultants and 28 person-months of national consultants.  
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
2.  Energy sector specialist (team leader, international, 8 person-months intermittent over 
24 months). The consultant will be a postgraduate in the energy field with extensive working 
experience in developing renewable energy and/or energy efficiency, preferably in Southeast Asia, 
both within the public sector and through public–private partnerships (PPP). The consultant will 
undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Coordinate  all  the  activities  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  and  supervise  all 
consultants under the TA in coordination with SEF national focal points. 
(ii)  Provide the GMS countries with the necessary technical and advisory support for 
activities and discussions on renewable energy, clean fuels, energy efficiency, and 
related PPP issues at the SEF, including review of the SEF work program and 
design and/or implementation of priority activities under the TA. 
(iii)  Plan, coordinate, and organize the conduct of knowledge-sharing seminars under 
the SEF, including the choice of topics, speakers, and reference materials, with a 
focus on PPP options. 
(iv)  Develop  and  disseminate  renewable  energy,  clean  fuels,  and  energy  efficiency 
resource maps. 
(v)  Set and monitor performance targets; and mainstreaming of climate change and 
energy security concerns in renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency 
and national development plans, policies, and programs. 
(vi)  Coordinate with other ongoing ADB programs in the GMS on renewable energy, 
energy efficiency, and climate change and energy security issues, especially with 
the RPTCC, the EOC, the Subregional Transport Forum, and the Working Group on 
Agriculture.  
(vii)  Assist in facilitating the establishment of a community of practice among the SEF 
coordinators and partner agencies, and in making the GMS a pilot showcase for a 
low carbon technology marketplace.  
(viii)  Provide guidance to the other TA consultants on their work program/focus and 
networking and coordination arrangements with SEF members and other partners. 
(ix)  Ensure that the regional database on renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy 
efficiency best practices and performance indicators contains updated information 
as presented to the SEF. 
(x)  Identify subregional and national barriers, and develop PPP business models for 
renewable energy, clean fuel, and energy efficiency technologies and identification 
of five pilot project proposals. 
(xi)  Lead the development and dissemination of policy manuals on renewable energy, 
clean fuels, and energy efficiency promotion; and integration of climate change and 
energy security concerns in energy plans and programs.  
(xii)  Prepare detailed concept papers, proposals for priority initiatives and/or activities, 
and  issues  and  background  papers  for  SEF  meetings  and  knowledge-sharing 
seminars. 
(xiii)  Prepare a knowledge-sharing dissemination plan and submit reports on meetings of 
the SEF and other relevant GMS working groups pertaining to renewable energy,

Appendix 3  9 
clean fuels, and energy efficiency issues, and other relevant reports identified during 
TA implementation, such as TA inception, midterm, and final reports. 
 
3.  Renewable energy specialist (international, 8 person-months intermittent over 24 months). 
The  consultant  will  be  a  graduate  in  the  field  of  energy,  preferably  with  experience  in  the 
development of renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency promotion programs in Asia. 
The consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Undertake  comparative  analysis  of  international  experiences  in  promoting 
renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency technologies; and document 
and/or recommend appropriate practices and lessons learned for GMS.countries.   
(ii)  Develop the format and content of the regional database of renewable energy, clean 
fuels, and energy efficiency best practices and performance indicators; and work 
with the data systems specialist in setting up the database. 
(iii)  Review and refine regional energy performance targets discussed in the SEF, and 
propose  compliance  and  monitoring  mechanisms  for  consideration  at  the  SEF 
meetings. 
(iv)  Review  findings  of  past  renewable  energy,  clean  fuels,  and  energy  efficiency 
assessment studies; and disseminate lessons derived from these studies, such as 
key barriers to renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency promotion and 
technology transfer. 
(v)  Research the quantitative benefits of renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy 
efficiency initiatives; translate these benefits in the GMS context; and develop and 
implement a plan for raising GMS awareness of such benefits. 
(vi)  Identify issues that require further studies with appropriate terms of reference. 
 
4.  Energy policy specialist (international, 4 person-months intermittent over 24 months). The 
consultant  will  be  a graduate  in  energy  sciences  with  postgraduate  training  or  experience  in 
renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency promotion and climate change issues, with 
strong report writing and organizational skills. The consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Review international experiences and literature on climate change mainstreaming in 
renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency plans, policies, and programs; 
integrating energy security in climate change plans; and disseminating renewable 
energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency technology and promotion practices. 
(ii)  Develop a policy manual and/or guidelines based on the results of the review in (i), 
and seek SEF consideration and endorsement of the manual and/or guidelines. 
(iii)  Undertake a training needs assessment in climate change and energy security 
issues; and renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency promotion. 
(iv)  Design training curricula and develop training manuals and materials. 
(v)  Assess the renewable energy and clean fuels resource potential of GMS countries, 
determine prospective areas for energy audits, and document the findings through 
production of resource maps and/or atlas. 
(vi)  Identify areas for renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency feasibility 
studies and pilot project proposals; oversee the conduct of these studies by national 
consultants; and package these proposals for SEF consideration and financing by 
the Clean Development Mechanism or other sources.

10  Appendix 3 
B.  National Consultants 
 
5.  Management information systems specialist (national, 4 person-months, continuous). 
The  consultant  will  be  a  graduate  in  social  science  with  postgraduate  training  in  database 
development and management, and strong report writing and organizational skills. The consultant 
will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Design and develop the SEF database based on the content (renewable energy, 
clean fuels, and energy efficiency focus) specified by the TA team. 
(ii)  Define the strategic information requirements to enhance the relevance, timeliness, 
and effectiveness of the database and the dissemination capabilities of its web 
component.  
(iii)  Provide the GMS countries with the necessary technical and advisory support for 
development of the renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency database 
and information system.  
(iv)  Advise the TA team on the most feasible database design and interfaces for data 
entry,  query  and  retrieval,  and  linkage  with  databases  of  the  United  Nations 
Framework Convention on Climate Change and the RPTCC.  
(v)  Advise the TA team on information security issues and interoperability concepts. 
(vi)  Submit a comprehensive report on the database developed, and its management 
and maintenance. 
 
6.  National consultants (national, 6 persons, for a total of 24 person-months, intermittent 
over 24 months). The national consultants will be a graduate in energy or environmental sciences 
with experience in renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency promotion and climate 
change issues, and strong report writing and organizational skills. The consultants will undertake 
the following activities in their respective countries: 
 
(i)  Collect data and ensure their translation from the national language to English as 
required. 
(ii)  Assist in research on past renewable energy, clean fuels, and energy efficiency 
assessment studies in their respective countries; and provide inputs for the in-
country  renewable  energy  and  clean  fuels  resource  assessments  and  energy 
efficiency audits. 
(iii)  Identify and recommend national best practices, technologies, and relevant national 
pilot project proposals; and help in packaging these studies and/or proposals for 
consideration at the SEF and for financing. 
(iv)  Assist in refining regional performance targets by providing inputs relevant to their 
respective countries. 
(v)  Provide inputs and/or information to the database of best practices and technology. 
(vi)  Participate in the organization of national training seminars. 
(vii)  Assist in implementing an information and awareness campaign, and monitoring in-
country feedback.
